work_title: Yoga Sastra: The Yoga Sutras of Patanjali examined with a notice of Swami Vivekananda's Yoga philosophy

sources: BKS Iyengar and others count: 196 sutras
fact_checks.notes: There is a minor discrepancy between 195 and 196 sutras depending on the tradition and commentator. Both numbers are acceptable; 196 is commonly cited in modern sources.

fact_checks.claim: Patanjali lived 2nd century BCE to 5th century CE
fact_checks.notes: Traditional dating places Patanjali around 2nd century BCE. Modern scholars suggest 2nd-5th century CE, with Philipp A. Maas dating the text to approximately 400 CE. The grammarian Patanjali (Mahabhasya author) is firmly dated to 2nd century BCE but is likely a different person.

fact_checks.claim: Eight limbs of Yoga (Ashtanga) in specific order

fact_checks.notes: Yoga Sutras build upon Samkhya metaphysics, distinguishing between Purusha (consciousness) and Prakriti (nature/matter). Yoga is sometimes called 'Samkhya with God' due to incorporation of Ishvara concept.

fact_checks.claim: John Murdoch founded/led Christian Literature Society for India
fact_checks.notes: Murdoch was Agent and Travelling Secretary for the Christian Vernacular Education Society in India from 1858. The organization was renamed The Christian Literature Society in 1891. He retired in 1903.
Raja Yoga was published in 1896, providing an interpretation of Patanjali's Yoga Sutras that made Eastern philosophy accessible to Western audiences.
Vivekananda delivered a landmark speech in September 1893, opening with 'Sisters and brothers of America!' to approximately seven thousand attendees.

Yogabhashya is traditionally attributed to Vyasa and is the earliest known commentary. However, some scholars including Philipp Maas suggest that Patanjali himself may have authored both the sutras and the bhashya commentary.
John Murdoch's examination of the Yoga Sutras with comparison to Vivekananda was published in 1897, one year after Vivekananda's Raja Yoga (1896).

notes: All major factual claims have been verified through multiple reliable sources. Minor variations exist in sutra counts (195 vs 196) and Patanjali dating, which reflect legitimate scholarly debates rather than factual errors.
